qas.question: WHo reformed the grand duchy army?
vytautas created what for compromising professional warriors?
What names did the newly formed noble families take afteR?

answers.text: Lithuanian pagan given names of their ennobled ancestors

qas.question: What is an example of noble family name?
Who gave the coat of arms to others?

context: In the late 14th century, in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, <a0_0>Vytautas the Great<a0_0/> reformed the Grand Duchy's army: instead of calling all men to arms, he created forces comprising professional warriors—<a1_0>bajorai<a1_0/> ("nobles"; see the cognate "boyar"). As there were not enough nobles, Vytautas trained suitable men, relieving them of labor on the land and of other duties; for their military service to the Grand Duke, they were granted land that was worked by hired men (veldams). The newly formed noble families generally took up, as their family names, the <a2_0>Lithuanian pagan given names of their ennobled ancestors<a2_0/>; this was the case with the <a3_0>Goštautai,<a3_0/> Radvilos, Astikai, Kęsgailos and others. These families were granted their coats of arms under the <a4_0>Union of Horodlo<a4_0/> (1413).
